head.citation-title: Research and development of a gesture-controlled robot manipulator system
head.abstracts: Â© 2016 IEEE.In this paper we present the results of research and development of a gesture-controlled robot manipulator system. The accelerometer and gyroscope inertia measurement unit helped estimate human arm's joint angles in stress test conditions. Four inertia measurement units were mounted on the following human arm parts: humerus, ulna, hand and finger. The estimation of human arm unfolding was done on a plane perpendicular to the earth by using free fall decomposition based on quaternions model. In dynamic environment accelerometer axis signals contain noise usually higher than base signal in addition to gravitational component. Coming from the approach of Maximum relative Entropy we construct posterior distribution based on Bayes Theorem. The likelihood distribution includes both observed values and nonlinear model relationships. In comparison, the prediction stage of Kalman Filter contains the model translation. Whereas the main difference is that we use multiple most recent observed samples instead of recursive approach. This allowed to stably decompose gravitational acceleration vector from measurement data. High speed data filtering performs Bayesian updating and finds the mean of posterior probability density function derived from maximization of relative entropy. This enables the control of remote robotic arm in harsh environments where shocks and vibrations exist. We experimented with this robotic system and demonstrated expected behavior of the manipulator when artificial shocks and vibrations were applied.
